channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: 10 questions, and don’t forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Employers added 50,000 jobs in December, a solid gain capping off weak 2025
item.description: The unemployment rate ticked down to 4.4 percent at the end of the worst year for the labor market since the pandemic-era recession.

item.title: Friday briefing: Minneapolis ICE shooting; White House ballroom; Grok images; health tips for 2026; and more
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: ICE officer who fatally shot a Minneapolis woman in her SUV had been dragged by a driver months earlier
item.description: Federal authorities did not publicly name the officer who killed Renee Nicole Good. But court records reviewed by The Washington Post of the prior incident in Bloomington, a suburb of Minneapolis, identify the officer as Jonathan Ross, who works for an Immigration and Customs Enforcement division that detains immigrants for civil violations and attempts to deport them.

item.title: Federal agents shoot two people in Portland, Oregon, mayor says
item.description: The victims’ conditions were not made public. Mayor Keith Wilson (D) did not identify the agency to which the federal agents who fired the shots belonged but called for Immigration and Customs Enforcement to end all operations in the city and referenced the fatal shooting of a woman by an ICE officer in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: House passes bill extending health care subsidies for 3 years, bucking GOP leaders. Its fate in the Senate remains unclear.
item.description: More than a dozen House Republicans joined every Democrat to pass a bill to extend enhanced Affordable Care Act subsidies — the sharpest rejection by GOP members of the party’s leadership yet. The pandemic-era subsidies expired at the end of last year, driving up costs for millions of Americans who buy health insurance on the ACA marketplace and qualified for the assistance.

item.title: Trump is planning to make his addition as tall as the mansion itself, breaking with architectural norms
item.description: The president’s architect disclosed the change as federal review panels begin a fast-track review of the $400 million project. The significant change of plans defies long-standing norms requiring additions to be shorter than the main building.

item.title: Senate advances bill to block further military action in Venezuela. The measure still awaits final passage.
item.description: The headline of a previous alert incorrectly stated the Senate had passed the bill. The Senate voted to advance the measure toward final passage, though the timing for a vote was not immediately clear.

item.title: Minnesota officials say the FBI is freezing the state out of the probe into the deadly ICE shooting
item.description: The Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension said the FBI’s decision to take over the investigation into the shooting in Minneapolis will keep state officials from accessing evidence.

item.title: Senate passes bill to block further military action in Venezuela
item.description: Though largely symbolic, the vote was a rare assertion of Congress’ role in using lethal force after the stunning raid to capture Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: My ex ‘brainwashed’ our girls to back his lawsuit against me
item.description: Ask Sahaj: My ex ‘brainwashed’ our girls to back his lawsuit against me

item.title: Heritage Foundation paper calls for ‘marriage bootcamp,’ discourages online dating, among other ideas
item.description: The conservative think tank aims to boost U.S. marriage and birth rates through recommendations to restrict pornography, create tax credits for bigger families while capping alimony payments and more.

item.title: The tragedy in Minnesota underscores a moral and political failure, the Editorial Board writes
item.description: Rioting in response to fatal shooting plays into Trump’s hands.

item.title: Pass this dessert item in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Footage shows ICE agent in Minneapolis fired at driver as vehicle veered past him
item.description: A deadly encounter in Minneapolis between federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents and a 37-year-old woman escalated in a matter of seconds. A frame-by-frame analysis of video footage raises questions about officials’ accounts.

item.title: ICE shooting. Greenland threats. Dietary advice. United Nations. Heritage report. AI job threat. Daydreaming. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Wizards to acquire four-time all-star Trae Young from Hawks for CJ McCollum, Corey Kispert
item.description: The trade for the point guard adds a key piece to the rebuilding Wizards, who have the youngest roster in the NBA and the second-most players age 22 or younger. Young is averaging 25.2 points per game over his eight-year career, and his 9.8 assists per game are the most among active players.

item.title: Rep. Steny Hoyer to retire, ending storied career representing Maryland in Congress
item.description: The 86-year-old Hoyer, the third-longest-serving member of the House, said he decided not to seek a new term over the holidays with his family, feeling content with a career that never brought the brass ring of the House speaker’s gavel but put him at the center of this century’s biggest debates.

item.title: Experts say these 5 exercises are key to staying healthy and aging better
item.description: These simple moves can help you stay strong and build muscles as you age.

item.title: Trump’s swaggering campaign to buy — or seize — Greenland could damage American security for decades, David Ignatius writes
item.description: Trump’s Greenland fixation curdles into a crisis

item.title: The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, one of the oldest American newspapers, says it will close down, citing losses and labor rules
item.description: After losing a battle with unionized employees, the owners of 240-year-old paper have decided to shut it down. The newspaper will print its final edition on May 3, according to a statement.

item.title: ICE officer fatally shoots woman during Minneapolis operation
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security confirmed the incident, which took place amid the Trump administration’s massive enforcement operation in the city.

item.title: BFF is moving to fulfill her expat dreams. I’m so sad. Hax readers give advice.
item.description: BFF is moving to fulfill her expat dreams. I’m so sad. Hax readers give advice.

item.title: New dietary guidance under RFK Jr. pushes whole milk, discourages processed food
item.description: The Dietary Guidelines for Americans are updated every five years to recommend what people should eat and is considered a cornerstone of federal nutrition policy.

item.title: Why do empty restaurants seat us at bad tables? Ask your dining questions.
item.description: Why do empty restaurants seat us at bad tables? Ask your dining questions.

item.title: Europe draws red line on Greenland as Trump seems to bristle at suggestions he is endangering NATO
item.description: European efforts to manage President Donald Trump rather than confront him have been jolted by the U.S. president’s hawkish comments about “getting” Greenland.

item.title: Not running for reelection in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: U.S. seizes Russian-flagged tanker that fled Venezuela blockade
item.description: The tanker Marinera has been pursued by the U.S. Coast Guard for weeks. Marinera “has been secured,” a U.S. official told The Washington Post. “U.S. federal law enforcement personnel are currently on board it.”

item.title: Venezuela raid. Tulsi Gabbard. Jan. 6 website. CDC turmoil. ICE agents. Warm weather. Essential exercises. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: About 75 people were killed in Venezuela during military raid to capture Maduro, U.S. officials assess
item.description: The sizable death toll adds meaning to President Donald Trump’s public remarks that the operation he approved was “effective” but “very violent.” Details of the operation indicate that there were zero U.S. fatalities, but seven service members were injured, the Pentagon said.

item.title: White House floats military option for seizing Greenland, rattling Denmark and NATO
item.description: The rhetoric follows a dramatic U.S. raid in Venezuela and revives Trump’s long-standing focus on the Danish territory, transforming diplomatic discussions into fears of coercion. But U.S. military posture there remains unchanged.

item.title: Aldrich Ames, the most damaging CIA traitor in agency history, dies in prison at 84
item.description: Ames turned over the names of recruited Soviet and Warsaw Pact agents and information about hundreds of intelligence operations to Moscow in return for money. His actions reportedly caused the deaths of at least 10 recruited CIA or allied intelligence agents.

item.title: Brown University suspect admitted to planning shooting for a long time, prosecutors say
item.description: Federal officials released a transcript of short videos they said Claudio Manuel Neves Valente recorded in Portuguese. Police found Valente dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound Dec. 18 at a New Hampshire storage facility.

item.title: Baltimore Ravens part ways with coach John Harbaugh after 18 seasons
item.description: Under Harbaugh, the Ravens reached the playoffs 12 times and won a Super Bowl.

item.title: Fear grips Caracas as a new wave of repression is unleashed
item.description: Venezuela’s government has moved quickly to suppress any public expression of support for Nicolás Maduro’s ouster, launching a nationwide crackdown that has included the detention of journalists, the arrest of civilians and the deployment of armed gangs across the capital.

item.title: Wyoming Supreme Court strikes down first-of-its-kind ban on abortion pills
item.description: The court also rolled back a broader prohibition on abortions, citing a state constitution provision that guarantees residents the right to make health care decisions.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: They’ve become this mom’s free day care, and she has notes
item.description: Carolyn Hax: They’ve become this mom’s free day care, and she has notes

item.title: Trump might have his hubris checked in Venezuela, David Ignatius writes
item.description: The president has launched a violent process of change that he can’t fully control.

item.title: McMansions may be making homeowners miserable. Our columnist explains why.
item.description: As the size of the average American home has nearly doubled, the people living in them aren’t any happier.

item.title: Rep. Doug LaMalfa (R-California) has died at 65. His passing challenges the GOP’s House majority.
item.description: The seven-term congressman represented a district that encompassed much of Northern California’s interior. His district was redrawn last year, taking it from a safely GOP seat to a Democratic-leaning one.

item.title: A memorable character in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Maduro in court. Childhood vaccines. Pete Hegseth. FEMA cuts. Grok images. ADHD drugs. Fiber advice. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Documents outline potential cuts affecting thousands of FEMA disaster responders
item.description: Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem has said she wants to reduce FEMA’s staff by half. Drafted plans show how it can happen.

item.title: This fun hobby may reduce your dementia risk by 76 percent
item.description: There are several science-based ways to boost your brain health, Dr. Trisha Pasricha writes, but this one might surprise you.

item.title: U.S. overhauls childhood vaccine schedule, recommending fewer shots
item.description: The new strategy would no longer broadly recommend vaccines for RSV, flu, hepatitis A and B, rotavirus and meningitis. The Trump administration says this aligns the U.S. with peer countries.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Husband does travel — just not with spouse to visit family
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Husband does travel — just not with spouse to visit family

item.title: Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro is set to appear in court for his arraignment in Manhattan. Follow our coverage.
item.description: The deposed Venezuelan leader has been transferred by helicopter to Manhattan, where he and his wife, Cilia Flores, are set to be arraigned at noon at the U.S. District Court on charges that they enriched themselves through drug trafficking.

item.title: There’s some turbulence in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Hegseth announces censure and potential demotion of Sen. Mark Kelly
item.description: The Trump administration has targeted the Arizona Democrat, a retired Navy officer, over a video reminding U.S. troops they can disobey illegal orders.

item.title: Is college worth it? This quiz shows the reality.
item.description: Views on the importance of higher education have fallen sharply in recent years.
